unnormalised: The sun beat down on Kamala’s face, a familiar warmth after a morning spent tending her small patch of organic okra near Nagpur. Kamala, a farmer in her late 50s, wasn’t always an organic enthusiast. For years, she, like many others in her village of Ramtek, relied on chemical fertilizers and pesticides to boost yields. She’d seen neighbours like Ramesh rake in impressive harvests, but the rising costs of chemicals and the increasingly depleted soil had started to worry her.

Kamala, a farmer in her late fifties, wasn’t always an organic enthusiast. For years, she, like many others in her village of Ramtek, relied on chemical fertilizers and pesticides to boost yields. She’d seen neighbours like Ramesh rake in impressive harvests, but the rising costs of chemicals and the increasingly depleted soil had started to worry her.

unnormalised: It was Dr. Sharma from the Krishi Vigyan Kendra (Agricultural Science Centre) who opened her eyes to the possibilities of organic farming. He conducted a workshop in their village, explaining the principles of sustainable agriculture, composting, and the benefits of using bio-pesticides like neem oil. Kamala was initially hesitant, remembering her father’s stories about low yields in the pre-Green Revolution era.

unnormalised: “Will it really work?” she had asked Dr. Sharma, her voice laced with doubt. “Will I be able to feed my family if I don’t use DAP and urea?”
normalised: “Will it really work?” she had asked Doctor Sharma, her voice laced with doubt. “Will I be able to feed my family if I don’t use D A P and urea?”

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma patiently explained that while the initial transition might see a slight dip in production, the long-term benefits of healthier soil, reduced input costs, and higher market prices for organic produce would outweigh the challenges. He also introduced her to the concept of Panchagavya, a traditional Indian concoction made from cow dung, urine, milk, curd, and ghee, used as a natural fertilizer and pest repellent. Kamala, a devout Hindu, resonated with this holistic approach.

unnormalised: That was three years ago. Now, Kamala’s farm, though only about 1000 sq ft, is a thriving example of organic principles. She uses cow dung manure from her own cattle, meticulously composts kitchen waste, and sprays neem oil regularly. Her okra plants are strong and vibrant, and she even cultivates a small vegetable garden with tomatoes, spinach, and brinjals, all organically grown.

unnormalised: She sells her produce at the weekly haat bazaar in Ramtek, fetching a slightly higher price than conventionally grown vegetables. The customers appreciate the taste and the assurance that they are consuming pesticide-free food. More importantly, Kamala’s soil is regaining its health. Earthworms, once absent, are now abundant, a testament to the revitalizing power of organic practices.

unnormalised: The transition wasn’t easy. There were pest infestations initially, and yields were lower than before in the first year. But Kamala persevered, relying on Dr. Sharma’s guidance and her own growing understanding of natural farming. She now spends significantly less on inputs – maybe Rs. 5000 per year compared to the Rs. 15000 she used to spend on chemicals.

unnormalised: Looking out at her small but flourishing farm, Kamala smiles. She is no longer just a farmer; she is a steward of the land, nurturing it back to life, one organic okra at a time. Her success is slowly inspiring others in Ramtek to consider a shift towards organic methods, creating a ripple effect of sustainable agriculture in the heart of Maharashtra. Even Ramesh, the farmer who initially had impressive harvests, is now seeking Kamala's advice. The journey is long, maybe even 20 km longer, but worth it.
